channel.title: ASF JIRA
channel.description: This file is an XML representation of an issue

item.title: [COLLECTIONS-838] Calling SetUtils.union on multiple instances of SetView causes JVM to hang
item.description:
hi,

 

Please have a look at the attached test class. If I call the SetUtils.union multiple times (~40) the JVM hangs. However, it will complete if I reduce the iterations (~30). 

 

Stack Trace:

 
"main" #1 prio=5 os_prio=31 cpu=829612.28ms elapsed=839.75s tid=0x000000015d008a00 nid=0x1803 runnable  [0x000000016ffc1000]
   java.lang.Thread.State: RUNNABLE

item.summary: Calling SetUtils.union on multiple instances of SetView causes JVM to hang

status.description: A resolution has been taken, and it is awaiting verification by reporter. From here issues are either reopened, or are closed.

comments.comment:
tambre 

A union() creates a view, so you are creating 40 layers of views in the test but it looks like you are typing to a Set, not a SetView, so if you care only about Sets, use toSet() on the result of calling union().

ggregory - we have now invoked "toSet()" that in our code to move forward. The reason I wanted to highlight this problem was many a times these objects are sent over the network or stored in binary format in no-sql db. In our use case we were doing "union()" only on 2 sets - the output was stored in a key-value db. On each new event we were retrieving the output from DB and doing a "union()" of it with a new set. hence we had this layering issue. 

Since SetView can be typed to Set, its easy to reach that stage. Hence I thought of highlighting this issue.

tambre 

Thank you for your report.

I suppose the question remains: Is your intent to create a view (immutable) on the union of two sets or an actual union of two sets?

ggregory - its to have an actual union of two sets. Hence we have changed the code to use "toSet()".

Point I was trying to make is - its very easy to start using SetView as a Set and stall the JVM inadvertently.

TBH, I didn't quite get the initial response on the bug, but I find it strange that it doesn't get fixed. 

We stumbled upon the same issue and had to introduce our own SetUtils that fixes this problem. 

In our case it was a constructor accepting an Iterable that used further Set.copyOf having the result of SetUtils.union provided into it having before it cast to a Collection (because it's a collection). And JVM got to hang there.

Intuitively, one would expect that the result of SetUtils.union could be safely used anywhere a Set is accepted. However, this doesn't seem to be the case in practice.

Could this issue be prioritized for resolution? I'm happy to provide additional details about our use case if helpful.

Gomoliako 

If you're not happy with the progress of any issue, the best path forward is to offer a solution in the form of a pull request on GitHub (with a unit test)

You got to know the power of exponential growth (or the  https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Wheat_and_chessboard_problem ),
as the contract of SetUtils.SetView is, that it reflects the changes of the mother/father sets. You are not interested
in that in your use case.

The 30 times chaining takes about 5s on my machine, 31 takes 10s, 32 takes 20s, 33->40s and so on.

Though in theory one could do something like checking the implementation class of the
mother/father sets, that becomes far to complicated (each combination of operations would need to be handled
differently). 

So I would only criticize, that this is not obvious from javadoc.

My suggestion is to

a) add something like this to SetUtils.SetView class javadoc

     * <p> Performance Warning: Chaining instances of SetView (by repeatedly
     *     invoking union, difference, intersection, disjunction on results)
     *     comes with a significant performance penalty, as the duration of
     *     all set functions grow exponentionally with each additional chain
     *     chain element (chaining a trivial set more than 30 times results
     *     in multiple seconds invocation duration, which is going to double
     *     with every next chain element).
     *     In case you don't need the decorating aspect (= that the new
     *     SetView instance changes when the underlying chained sets change)
     *     of this API, directly invoke toSet() on each result of 
     *     union, difference, intersection or disjunction, which collapses it
     *     into a normal set, which you can then chain as often as needed.
     * </p>

 

b) add the following methods to SetUtils

    public static <E> Set<E> intersectionSet(...) 
    public static <E> Set<E> differenceSet( ... )
    public static <E> Set<E> disjunctionSet( ...) 
    public static <E> Set<E> unionSet( ... )

which then invoke
  return intersection(...).toSet();
etc.

ggregory : I can provide a PR for a) and/or b) that when this solution would be accepted in principle.

Ok, I created PR https://github.com/apache/commons-collections/pull/630 which updates javadoc for union, disjunction, diffrence and intersection and adds the 4 convenience methods unionSet, disjunctionSet, differenceSet, intersectionSet to explain to the API user, when to use which methods.

In case it is not obvious, OP's problem could either be fixed by switching the line

return SetUtils.union(set1, set2);

to 

return SetUtils.union(set1, set2).toSet();

(already possible in current version  or in case PR gets accepted by using 

return SetUtils.unionSet(set1, set2);

Hi jbudi,

Thanks for your note about the exponential performance of SetUtils.union(): that was the missing piece in understanding this issue. It’s true that using views instead of copies will degrade performance, but for union() I would expect a quadratic slowdown in the number of sets, not an exponential degradation.

After digging deeper, the root cause seems to be IteratorChain. In particular, it calls hasNext() on its nested iterators twice for every hasNext() invocation, which amplifies the cost exponentially.

Rather than just documenting the poor performance in the Javadoc, I suggest we:

  1. Optimize IteratorChain so that delegated iterators have hasNext() called at most once per invocation. This should directly address the current problem.
  2. Consider an UnmodifiableIteratorChain for cases that don’t require remove(). This could yield smaller but worthwhile performance gains. (Worth a separate issue.)
  3. Enhance set union logic so that the union of multiple sets can unwrap any parameters that are themselves unions. This should also be tracked separately.

Even with Stream and Flow, Iterator remains a fundamental abstraction in the Java ecosystem. Investing in logic that can fuse or collapse wrapped iterators would have lasting benefits across the library.

FYI: This issue was fixed on master via https://github.com/apache/commons-collections/pull/633 and thus will be in next commons-collections release (probably 4.5.1).
Thx to pkarwasz for his thoughts and guidance, which made the difference to get a real fix instead of just a workaround as I earlier suggested.

jbudi,

Thanks for the fix.

Although your PR doesn’t introduce any API changes, I’m setting the fixed version to 4.6.0, based on JApiCmp’s recommendation for other changes currently in master.
